awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: The educational objectives of the Interactive Biomaterials REU Site at Syracuse University are: to train students in leading-edge research techniques through independent biomaterials research projects in a multidisciplinary, collaborative, and open laboratory environment; to provide multifaceted mentoring opportunities and network-building experiences that ultimately increase the likelihood that participants will pursue graduate education in their chosen discipline; and to train students to be effective communicators of their research to their peers and the scientific community. These objectives are accomplished through participation in independent, interactive biomaterials research projects in faculty laboratories, one-on-one mentoring from faculty advisors and graduate student mentors, an innovative career mentoring program, student research presentations, team building activities, and social events. The REU Site aims to engage undergraduate students in meaningful and stimulating research and educational and social experiences as a means of increasing their enthusiasm and preparation for future graduate level study and careers in biomaterials science and engineering.
  
TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: The research projects available to students in the REU will advance fundamental scientific knowledge in areas that include shape memory polymers, stimulus-responsive polymers, drug delivery, control of bacterial biofilms, cell-biomaterial interactions, tissue engineering, and molecular modeling of interactive biomaterials. These hypothesis-driven, multidisciplinary research projects draw upon the collective expertise of the faculty of the Syracuse Biomaterials Institute, and, in many cases, foster collaborative research across faculty laboratories, academic departments, and institutions. Distinguishing characteristics and contributions of the Interactive Biomaterials REU Site include: an educational experience that starts with efficient and effective team building and then centers on research projects appropriate to the undergraduate but sufficiently challenging to allow for students to make meaningful contributions for which they are trained to clearly communicate to diverse technical or lay audiences and readerships; a research environment that provides world class multidisciplinary laboratory facilities and diverse projects and mentors from across three participating institutions who are trained and continually supported by the REU Site leadership throughout the program; a student recruitment and selection process that yields diverse cohorts carefully matched to projects and faculty mentors to maximize the educational experience of the students; and rich and diverse integrated professional development activities designed to support and launch the students' professional goals without distracting from the fundamental research experience.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of the Interactive Biomaterials REU Site are: To train students in leading-edge research techniques through independent biomaterials research projects in a multidisciplinary, collaborative, and open laboratory environment; To provide multifaceted mentoring opportunities and network-building experiences that ultimately increase the likelihood that participants will pursue graduate education in their chosen discipline; and To train students to be effective communicators of their research to their peers and the scientific community. 

During the summers of 2018-2022 (with 2020 skipped due to the COVID-19 pandemic), a total of 35 undergraduate students from across the country participated in the REU Site. Those students experienced: an educational experience that starts with efficient and effective team building and then centers on research projects appropriate to the undergraduate but sufficiently challenging to allow for students to make meaningful contributions; a research environment that provides world-class multidisciplinary laboratory facilities and diverse projects and mentors; a student recruitment and selection process that yields diverse cohorts carefully matched to projects and faculty mentors to maximize the educational experience of the students; rich and diverse integrated professional development activities designed to support and launch the students'professional goals without distracting from the fundamental research experience; and cost-effective management of the site and outcomes based on continuous improvement of programmatic effectiveness via assessment and feedback.

In terms of the program's intellectual merit, assessment data gathered by our evaluation team via exit surveys administered in the final week of the program each year clearly demonstrate that the site achieved all three of the educational objectives. For example, for the 2021 cohort (the final full, 10-student cohort before a no-cost extension in 2022; all percentages based on 9 respondents, unless noted): 100% of students indicated they had made either great (66.7%) or moderate (33.3%) gains in familiarity with a range of research techniques, and 100% of students also indicated they had made either great (66.7%) or moderate (33.3%) gains in mastery of project-specific research techniques. 44.4% of students indicated they were more likely to apply to a Master's or PhD program in STEM. 100% of students indicated they had made great (66.7%) or moderate (33.3%) gains in making oral presentation of their research, and 100% of students indicated they had made great (77.8%) or moderate (22.2%) gains in explaining their project to people outside of their field. As further illustration of the program's merit, students indicated the following noteworthy gains. Preparing a scientific poster: 100% indicated either great (88.9%) or moderate (11.1%) gains. Writing scientific reports or papers: 100% indicated either great (55.6%) or moderate (44.4%) gains. Preparation for graduate school: 100% (8/8) indicated either great (50%) or moderate (50%) gains. Preparation for academic or industrial careers: 100% (8/8) indicated either great (50%) or moderate (50%) gains. Interest in biomaterials research/careers: 75% (6/8) indicated either great (37.5%) or moderate (37.5%) gains. Interest in some other scientific research/career: 87.5% (7/8) indicated either great (62.5%) or moderate (25%) gains. Confidence in their ability to contribute to science: 100% (8/8) indicated great (62.5%) or moderate (37.5%) gains. In addition, the Interactive Biomaterials REU Site frequently achieved student-authored publications from a given cohort, with 3 REU co-authored papers published in the most recent (2022-2023) reporting period. 

In terms of the program's broader impacts, an alumni survey administered in June 2023 found that of the 32 alumni respondents, 44% (14/32) are currently enrolled in undergraduate or graduate programs (8 PhD, 3 MD, 2 MS, and 2 BS), and 17 of the remaining 18 are employed, all (100%) in STEM-related jobs (the remaining alum is hiking the Appalachian Trail). Of the 17 STEM-employed alumni (59% [10/17] in industry, 35% [6/17] in academia, 6% [1/17] in government), 24% (4/17) are working in biomaterials-related areas. 86% of alumni indicated that participation in the Interactive Biomaterials REU had a positive effect on their commitment to a career/further education in STEM. In addition, when asked "To what extent did your participation in the Biomaterials REU help you to become more proficient in the following areas?," alumni reported the following lasting impact. Interpreting data:100% indicated increased proficiency to a great extent (48%) or some extent (52%). Interpreting technical content: 100% indicated increased proficiency to a great extent (59%) or some extent (41%). Performing research:100% indicated increased proficiency to a great extent (72%) or some extent (28%). Networking: 89% indicated increased proficiency to a great extent (55%) or some extent (34%). Presenting research orally: 96% indicated increased proficiency to a great extent (34%) or some extent (62%). 

Collectively, these data clearly demonstrate that the Site has achieved long-term, lasting impact related to all three educational objectives. 

 


Last Modified: 07/13/2023
Modified by: James H Henderson
